newsitem.title: SOUTH AFRICA: LONRHO, JCI CAUTIONS FURTHER.
newsitem.headline: LONRHO, JCI CAUTIONS FURTHER.

text.p: Lonrho Plc and JCI Ltd said on Friday they were still in preliminary talks to indentify any benefits from combining the two groups.
The two companies warned their shareholders and that of Tweefontein United Collieries Ltd and Duiker Mining Ltd to exercise caution in their share dealings.

"Shareholders are advised that preliminary talks with representatives of JCI Ltd are bEing held in order to identify the scope for any benefits from combining the Lonrho and JCI groups," Lonrho said in a statement.
But the statement said no proposal for the terms of any such transaction has been tabled or considered by Lonrho's Board.
JCI and Lonrho confirmed on Monday that they were in talks on a possible merger which could create a mining company with market capitalisation of more than $3 billion.

The Financial Times reported on Thursday that JCI chairman Mzi Khumalo, who heads South Africa's first black-controlled mining firm, was confident and optimistic that a deal can be reached for a merger with Lonrho.
"JCI wants a broad agreement pretty soon. After that, we can handle the detailed, technical work," he said.
But Business Day newspaper reported on Tuesday that Avmin Ltd and Gencor Ltd were also interested in tying up with Lonrho.
Both companies have said they will not comment on the report.
Last month the European Commission forced Anglo American of South Africa Ltd to cut its 27.5 percent stake in Lonrho to 9.99 percent over the next two years.
The Commission said Anglo platinum interests combined with that of Lonrho would put control of the world's platinum industry in the hands of Anglo and Gencor.
Khumalo, who made the initial approach to the conglomerate, added that he would return to London on Monday for what he hoped would be final talks.

"When it became clear that the European Union would not allow Anglo American to maintain its 27 percent take in Lonrho, I knew it was open season and that JCI had to make its move," he told the Financial Times.
